title: solr CPU 100%
description:
CPU was high on 3.4 version as well. We upgraded just the solr.war to the latest version(3.6) hoping it will resolve the high CPU issue. 
Notice there are a lot of BLOCKED threads below. This is the complete thread dump captured through the admin screen.


	restarting the search server does not make any difference.
	removed data directory and reindex all documents from scratch - no effect.
Has anybody seen this error?



Solr Admin ()

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
The point where your server blocks on is not in Lucene 3.4 (the MapBackedSet is only used since Lucene 3.6 for thread safety and prevention of Segmentation faults), so the issue cannot come from the blocked threads itsself.

It is very strange that you have so many concurrent threads opening IndexInputs, so it looks like your IO-System is completely overloaded. How many IO-Waits do you have (look into top), because this seems to be caused by starvation on cloning IndexInputs?

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
In general, there are way too many threads actively doing searching. If you have so high load on your server, buy some more of them and distribute your searches better to more machines.
You should maybe limit the number of acceptor threads in your servlet container. 500 is too much concurrency.

comments.author: Madhav Vodnala
comments.content:
Thanks for the hints. Found the reason and the solution. One of the applications was issuing commit every 5 seconds. It was a bug; we removed commit from all applications and the CPU is back
to normal, 3-5% and 70-80% for a second (when the autocommit kicks in). We are now fully depending on Solr autoCommit. The lesson learnt is autoCommit is the only way to go in production Solr deployments.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
Thanks for reporting back!

Regarding the number of blocked threads: To minimize this blocking behavior I will open another issue to improve the MMapDirectory clones management.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content: I opened LUCENE-4163 to improve concurrency in MMapIndexInput.clone().

comments.author: Jan Høydahl
comments.content:
The lesson learnt is autoCommit is the only way to go in production Solr deployments.

I would rather recommend using commitWithin (http://wiki.apache.org/solr/CommitWithin) which gives you more flexibility, and also allows you to do bulk loading without frequent committing if you choose
